description:
Physically, the NorESM1-ME and NorESM1-M are very similar. The NorESM1-M simulates mainly physical components, whereas the NorESM1-ME is the official version where it includes all carbon cycle components in the CMIP5 runs (both prescribed atmospheric CO2 and emissions simulations) it performed.

There are some minor differences such as initial condition and small perturbation in cloud parameterization, but the main physical mean state and climate variability should be largely consistent and comparable.

responsibleParties.address:
Norges forskningsråd 
Postboks 2700 St. Hanshaugen 0131 Oslo 
Besøksadresse: Stensberggata 26

subComponents.description:
Description: Emissions for the sulphur cycle include emissions of sulphate aerosol precursors: sulphur dioxide and dimethylsulphide in addition to SO4 formed close to the emissions source( 2%).  For sulphur dioxide and SO4, anthropogenic and biomass burning emissions are taken from Lamarque et al. (2009). Natural emissions from volcanoes are provided as a 3D field. (Dentener et al., 2006) DMS emissions have no interannual variation, and  are taken from the day by day varying dataset from the year 2000 in Dentener et al. (2006).  All sulphur-cycle emissions are expressed in term of mass of sulphur within the model. For black-carbon and organic-carbon aerosols from fossil-fuel and biofuel emissions, emissions are provided at the two lowest model layers, following the classification in Dentener et al. 2006 together with the source classification in Lamarque et al (2009). For biomass-burning aerosol, emissions are provided from Lamarque et al. (2009) and distributed vertically as in Dentener et al. (2006). The climatology of monthly-averaged mass-mixing ratios of secondary organic aerosol from terpene emissions are taken from Dentener et al. (2006), but scaled to the total numbers in Hoyle et al. (2007). Primary organic matter from the ocean is parameterised by using the fine mode sea-salt emissions in Dentener et al. (2006) scaled to the number given in Spracklen et al. (2008). Emissions of organic carbon aerosols are expressed in term of mass of total organic matter.
Emissions from mineral dust are based on the year 2000 calculated in Dentener et al. (2006). Sea-salt aerosol emissions are computed interactively depending on modelled near-surface wind speeds and sea-surface temperatures (Struthers et al., 2011). All emission fields except DMS and dust are provided as monthly means, which are read in at the beginning of each moth. DMS and mineral dust are given as daily values, although with no interannual variation

subComponents.description: Background (primary) aerosol size modes are assumed to be log-normally distributed and have constant median radii and standard deviations at the point of emission. The size distributions for modified aerosol modes, after growth, are not restricted to log-normality. Although the modified aerosol size distributions are not calculated from "first principles" in the model itself, as in a sectional model, modal size parameters (for droplet activation and subsequent indirect effects) and aerosol optical properties (for the direct effect) are found from look-up tables (by interpolation in up to 5 dimensions) of values which have been computed with a separate code which takes into account growth by condensation (including hygroscopic growth), coagulation and wet-phase chemistry/cloud processing. These tables have been made for a large array of different input values for the amount of condensation, coagulation etc (relative to a background aerosol) for the various constituents.

values: Use same turbulence scheme as AtmosphericChemistry

properties.description: As described in Kirkevåg et al. (2013), the mass concentrations of selected aerosol species are calculated from prescribed and on-line emission sources by the atmospheric life-cycling scheme of anthropogenic and natural aerosol mass in the troposphere. Key aerosol properties, which enable estimating interactions with atmospheric radiation and cloud microphysics, are based on prescribing up to 4 log-normal size modes for each type of primary particles at the time of emission or nucleation, while secondary particle mass tagged to production mechanisms are used to diagnose modified size-distributions, aerosol optics, and aerosol water activation, using 44 bins.

subComponents.description: The bounary-layer turbulence scheme is "Holtslag-Boville" (Holtslag and Boville, 1993; Boville and Bretherton, 2003; Neale et al, 2010). The Zhang-McFarlane (Zhang and McFarlane, 1995) deep convection scheme has been changed by including the effects of deep convection in the momentum equation (Richter and Rasch, 2008) and using a dilute, rather than an undilute, approximation in the plume calculation (Neale et al., 2008), see also Neale et al. (2010) and Gent et al. (2011). The shallow convection scheme is described in Neale et al. (2010). The parameterization of non-convective cloud processes is described in Rasch and Kristjansson (1998) and Zhang et al. (2003). The aerosol-cloud interactions are described in Kirkevåg et al. (2012, in prep.), however, see the aerosol description.

The treatment of cloud vertical overlap follows Collins (2001), i.e. as in CAM4. Treatment of cloud micro- and macro-physics is in general as in CAM4, except for some tuning parameters and the special treatment of aerosol-cloud interactions which are specific to CAM4-Oslo. This special treatment (Kirkevåg et al., 2013) is based on but not identical to that of Hoose et al. (2010).

subComponents.description: The atmospheric dynamical core of NorESM / CAM4-Oslo is the same as in CAM4 (Lin, 2004; Gent et al., 2011).
Same as CCSM4: Tracer SchemeName is Flux-Form Semi-Lagrangian. ConservationMethod for Tracers and Momentum is monotonic PPM.

subComponents.description: SpongeLayer is implemented as diffusion near the model top as in CCSM4

Optical properties and treatment of radiative effects of ice clouds are as in  CAM4 (Neale et al, 2010). Also for liquid clouds the intrinsic optical properties are as in CAM4, but cloud droplet number concentrations and effective cloud droplet radii (for the radius indirect effect) and liquid water paths (for the life-time indirect effect) are calculated according to (Kirkevåg et al., 2013, see more references under the general description of aerosols in CAM4-Oslo).

properties.description:
Volcanoes implementation method: Tropospheric volcanic SO2 emissions. Constant, taken from year 2000. Treated as other SO2 emissions. 
Contributions to the stratospheric aerosols from large, explosive eruptions. Time varying, 1850-2005 monthly mean sulphate concentrations in the stratosphere (Amman et al (2003)). Treated as primary emitted sulphate accumulation mode for radiative purposes. Zero outside historical run

subProperties.description: The Solar constant is fixed (1367.0 W/m2) for the control simulation, but is otherwise as described in Lean et al. (2005). Experiments beyond year 2100 use the value given for year 2100.

subComponents.description: Sea ice albedo and short wave radiation is calculated with the Delta-Eddington scheme implemented in CICE and CCSM4 (Holland 2011; Briegleb and Light 2007). This scheme uses  microscopic inherent optical properties as scattering and absorption of snow, ice, melt ponds and included absorbers (black carbon and dust) to calculate macroscopic properties as albedo, transmittance, and total energy absorbed. Compared with CCSM4, NorESM1-M uses an increased snow grain size for cold snow to lower the albedo. This is done to increase summer melt of snow. Deposition of aerosols (black carbon and dust) on snow and ice are calculated interactively in the atmosphere model.
subComponents.longName: Thermodynamical properties of CICE sea ice model in NorESM1-M

values: Delta-Eddington scheme in snow and ice
Open water freezing delivered by ocean model, basal growth calculated in ice model
Multi-layer on a regular vertical grid
Thermal properties depending on S-T (fixed salinity)

properties.description: The NorESM1 uses the same sea-ice model as the CCSM4 model, which is based on the CICE4 model from  Los Alamos National Laboratory (Hunke and Lipscomb, 2008). This is a multi-category ice thickness model which solves the basic equation of Thorndike et al. (1975), to capture a sub-gridscale ice thickness distribution. NorESM1 uses 5 ice categories plus open water. The sea ice model is coupled with the atmosphere model every atmospheric radiation time-step. Surface fluxes are calculated in the sea ice model for each ice category. Coupling to the ocean is done ones a day.
properties.longName: Key properties of CICE sea ice model

values: Ice concentration, ice volume, snow volume, melting heat of ice, melting heat of snow, horizontal velocity, melt pond volume, aerosol concentrations in snow and ice
